name: COUNCIL ON AMERICAN-ISLAMIC RELATIONS CALIFORNIA
mission: CAIR works to protect and defend the constitutional rights of American Muslims, thereby supporting the rights of all Americans.
theoryOfChange: By combining legal action, policy advocacy, and community empowerment, CAIR-CA seeks to dismantle systemic Islamophobia and protect the constitutional rights of Muslims.

all_citations.claim: CAIR California works to protect the constitutional rights of American Muslims and maintains specific financial metadata.
The organization reported total revenue of $17,442,755, a program expense ratio of 83.7%, working capital of 14.5 months, and fundraising efficiency of $0.07 per $1 raised.
The charity is Zakat-eligible and maintains a policy regarding asnaf categories.
The organization provides various donation options and giving methods for donors.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: With a GMG score of 70/100, the organization demonstrates strong financial health and high donor alignment, particularly for those seeking Zakat-eligible advocacy opportunities.
areas_for_improvement: Expanding direct impact reporting to provide more granular cost-per-beneficiary data.
Increasing public documentation regarding long-term capacity building outcomes.

dimension_explanations.alignment: CAIR California shows high alignment for Muslim donors as a ZAKAT-ELIGIBLE institution that applies funds toward specific asnaf categories [3]. The organization addresses urgent cause areas including policy advocacy and media relations, providing multiple secure giving methods for supporters [4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization focuses on capacity building and civil rights advocacy, allocating 83.7% of its $17,442,755 revenue toward its core programs [2]. While it maintains a solid 14.5 months of working capital, the nature of advocacy work makes direct cost-per-beneficiary metrics less applicable than in direct service charities [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Council on American-Islamic Relations California defends the constitutional rights of American Muslims through robust legal advocacy and civil rights protections.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 83.7% ensures most funds directly support advocacy and civil rights work.
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.07 per $1 raised.
Strong liquidity with 14.5 months of working capital available to sustain operations.
baseline_narrative.summary: CAIR California operates as a leading civil rights organization dedicated to protecting the liberties of the Muslim community and promoting social justice for all Americans [1]. The organization reported a total revenue of $17,442,755 and maintains a high level of financial transparency through its public filings [2].

all_citations.quote: CAIR-CA is Zakat eligible. funds are used for Zakat-eligible categories

all_citations.claim: civil rights protection and legal services
all_citations.quote: Programs: Civil Rights Protection, Legal Services, Advocacy

all_citations.claim: Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid

all_citations.quote: Revenue growth from $7.7M to $17.4M over three years
No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: With a GMG score of 70/100, the organization demonstrates strong financial health and high donor alignment, particularly for those seeking Zakat-eligible advocacy opportunities.

areas_for_improvement.area_detail: While CAIR-CA tracks <cite id="6">5 outcome metrics</cite>, it currently lacks public <cite id="8">cost-per-beneficiary data</cite> which would allow for more precise effectiveness comparisons.
The organization's impact is currently <cite id="8">internally measured</cite>; pursuing an external third-party evaluation would strengthen its evidence base.

bbb_assessment.summary: Maintains high governance standards with a 93% independent board and audited financials.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization is actively tracking 5 outcome metrics and holds the highest transparency seal from Candid.
risk_factors: <cite id="8">No external third-party impact evaluation available</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary limitation is the <cite id="8">lack of granular cost-per-beneficiary data</cite> and the absence of a fully documented theory of change.

confidence.notes: Very high confidence due to recent 990 data and Platinum transparency seal.

alignment.explanation: The charity is a high-fit for Muslim donors, offering <cite id="3">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and serving the <cite id="3">ibn sabil (wayfarer) asnaf</cite> through its immigration and legal programs.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust CAIR-CA due to its <cite id="6">Platinum Seal of Transparency</cite> and a board with <cite id="1">93% independent membership</cite>. The organization has operated for nearly 30 years and maintains <cite id="2">audited financial records</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To further enhance credibility, the organization could <cite id="8">publish a clear theory of change</cite> with an explicit causal pathway for its advocacy work.

impact.explanation: With a <cite id="2">83.7% program expense ratio</cite>, the charity is highly efficient. It tracks <cite id="6">outcome metrics through Candid</cite> and provides critical <cite id="5">legal and immigration services</cite>.
impact.improvement: Impact reporting would benefit from <cite id="8">consistent publication of beneficiary counts</cite> to allow for cost-effectiveness assessments.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Outcome tracking via Candid

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Supports local partners in humanitarian and legal service delivery

rich_narrative.headline: The Council on American-Islamic Relations California defends the constitutional rights of American Muslims through robust legal advocacy and civil rights protections.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize civil rights protections for American Muslims and value highly efficient, zakat-eligible advocacy and legal defense.
donor_motivations: Want to protect the constitutional rights of the Muslim community
Value high financial efficiency with minimal overhead
Seek to fulfill zakat through legal and immigration support
Support long-term systemic change through advocacy
giving_considerations: Advocacy impact is often long-term and harder to quantify than direct aid
The organization has a very high program ratio, leaving little for administrative growth
Focus is primarily on California-based legal and civil rights issues
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking immediate, tangible international relief (e.g., food parcels) or those who require RCT-level evidence of impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The organization tracks <cite id="6">5 specific outcome metrics</cite> but lacks independent external evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: CAIR-CA uses legal services, media engagement, and community education to protect civil liberties and promote an accurate image of Muslims.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence in advocacy ensures that legal interventions and educational programs are effectively shifting public perception and protecting rights.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Rapid revenue growth suggests high absorption capacity for new advocacy initiatives.

organizational_capacity.geographic_reach: California (Orange County, San Diego, Los Angeles, Sacramento)

peer_comparison.differentiator: CAIR-CA's <cite id="2">83.7% program ratio</cite> significantly outperforms the <cite id="7">peer median of 77.5%</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focus on legal advocacy and civil rights
similar_organizations.name: Innocence Project

similar_organizations.differentiator: Regional advocacy with similar legal scope
similar_organizations.name: Project South

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="2">83.7% of its total expenses</cite> toward its programs, far exceeding the <cite id="7">peer program ratio median of 77.5%</cite> for advocacy groups.
CAIR-CA demonstrates elite fiscal management, spending only <cite id="1">$0.07 to raise every $1</cite> in contribution revenue.
The charity maintains <cite id="1">14.5 months of working capital</cite> in working capital, providing a significant buffer against economic volatility.

strengths_deep_dive: CAIR-CA's financial health is characterized by rapid growth and disciplined spending. The organization achieved a <cite id="7">3-year revenue CAGR of 49.7%</cite>, nearly doubling its budget between 2021 and 2023. This growth has been managed with high accountability; the board consists of <cite id="1">93% independent members</cite>, ensuring strong oversight of its <cite id="2">$23.3 million in total assets</cite>. Furthermore, its grantmaking capacity is substantial, with <cite id="2">$4,148,077 distributed to 39 domestic recipients</cite>, including major partners like the International Rescue Committee.
rich_narrative.summary: The Council on American-Islamic Relations California (CAIR-CA) serves as a critical legal and advocacy pillar for the American Muslim community, focusing on the defense of constitutional rights and the promotion of social justice. The organization operates at a significant scale, reporting <cite id="2">total revenue of $17,442,755</cite> in the 2023 tax year. CAIR-CA distinguishes itself through its high operational efficiency, maintaining a <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 83.7%</cite>, which ensures that the vast majority of donor contributions are directed toward its core missions of <cite id="5">civil rights protection and legal services</cite>. Beyond legal advocacy, the organization is a major grantmaker, distributing <cite id="2">$4,148,077 in domestic grants</cite> to support community partners and humanitarian efforts. This financial robustness is matched by a commitment to transparency, evidenced by its <cite id="6">Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>. By providing <cite id="5">immigration legal services and community education</cite>, CAIR-CA addresses systemic challenges facing Muslims in California while maintaining <cite id="1">14.5 months of working capital</cite> to ensure long-term organizational stability.
